I've delivered a LBP before.  There will be a predetermined order 
and you will all go back to back.  LBP's are not organized into 
categories so a panel wouldn't make much sense.   People who go to 
LBP sessions usually like the fact that they are faster paced than 
other presentations, so in other words if there's a paper you don't 
like it's over soon anyway.

By the way, check it out, the schedule is up at:

http://www-illigal.ge.uiuc.edu:8080/GECCO-2004/talk-schedule.html

You guys are 5th up in your session.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> All,
> 
> I'll be presenting our paper at GECCO during a Late-Breaking Paper
> session, and here are the instructions from the website:
> 
> http://www.isgec.org/gecco-2004/
> 
> "Late Breaking Paper (LBP) talks should take no more than 15 
minutes in total. 
> 
> Set-up of necessary presentation equipment should be calculated 
into
> the allotted presentation time."
> 
> They've got 8 LBP's scheduled during a 2 hour and 10 minute block 
in
> the same room.  I'd be interested to hear anyone's experiences 
during
> a presentation like this, as this is our first.  When I saw that
> they'd scheduled a group of presenters to a block, I thought it 
would
> be something like a panel format.  Or do we just draw straws and 
give
> our presentations back-to-back?
> 
> Derek
